results.title: Lena the glassblower: Sweden
results.creator_credit: Sunrise Films, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, Fred Harris and Peter Rowe
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World cultures and youth”.
The story of Lena, a 17-year-old girl who decides to become a glassblower against the wishes of her parents, who want her to take up tertiary education. As well as dealing positively with this conflict, the film shows many aspects of the craft of glassblowing - in particular, that carried out at the Orrefors establishment in Sweden. Suitable for upper primary, lower and middle secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sunrise Films, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, Fred Harris and Peter Rowe

results.title: Len Lye: interview with Tyler Cann
results.brief_description: Tyler Cann, Curator of the Len Lye Collection at the Govett-Brewster Art Gallery in New Plymouth, New Zealand, visited ACMI during the Len Lye exhibition. Tyler Cann spoke about Len Lye’s influential and enduring body of work noting that this retrospective at ACMI is the largest and most comprehensive exhibition of the artist’s work to date. He focuses on particular works, some of which were reconstructed specifically for the ACMI exhibition.

results.title: Len Lye's films. Vol. 1: Free radicals
results.creator_credit: Len Lye Foundation and Len Lye
results.brief_description: This collection of short animated films spans 50 years of Len Lye’s experimental filmmaking. All but ‘Rhythm’ (1957) use ‘direct film’ techniques dispensing with the camera to paint and scratch directly onto the film surface. Lye’s abstract films influenced and led the way for experimental filmmaking and filmmakers such as Norman McLaren and Stan Brakhage amongst many others. He incorporated musical soundtracks of mostly tribal and percussive themes that reflected his interest in rhythm and movement as in ‘Free radicals’ (1958) and ‘Particles in Space’(1979) as well as jazz and blues soundtracks (the music of Tal Farlow and Sonny Terry were also used).

results.title: Lemonheads: two weeks in Australia
results.creator_credit: Atlantic, Catherine Smith and Jesse Peretz
results.brief_description: The independant US band The Lemonheads first received mainstream attention when their album “It’s A Shame About Ray” broke through into the Top 40. We casually follow the band around Australia during the 1992 tour to promote the album. Utilising cinema verite techniques this program includes interviews with the band and live performances of many of their songs. It also features the promotional videos to a number of songs including: “It’s a Shame about Ray”, “Confetti”, “My Drug Buddy” and their unique version of Simon & Garfunkle’s “Mrs Robinson”.

results.title: Lemonade Joe [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Filmove Studio Barrandov, Jaroslav Jilovec and Oldrich Lipsky
results.brief_description: A Czech musical western that spoofs American cinema with obvious affection and demonstrates how the Czech New Wave film movement of the 1960s wasn’t limited to ruminations on the history, politics and art of Eastern Europe. Lemonade Joe (Karel Fiala) is the good-natured lemonade salesman who teams up with a temperance leader, the sweet blond Winnifred (Olga Schoberova), to defeat a local saloon and den of prostitution. With his capitalistic know-how and her ideological piety, they believe that they’ll soon have all of Arizona trading whisky for lemonade. Composed largely in whimsical sing-song rhyme with the characters breaking into song at every opportunity, the dialogue and tunes arise from a uniquely Czech interpretation of the American Western. In Czech with English subtitles.

results.title: Lelong court
results.brief_description: This short humorous docu-drama centres around a foley artist/sound effects specialist, Jean-Pierre Lelong and his role in making a film. Infatuated with the main actress Lelong meddles with the tricks of his trade to become the saboteur in an attempt to prevent the hero from being united with the film’s heroin. Gradually the film’s direction shifts as a result of Lelong’s work, but not with Lelong’s intended results. No spoken word, sound effects only. Cast includes Sylvie Loeillet, Jean-Pierre Lelong and Bernard Bourdeix.

results.title: Leisure time photography
results.brief_description: Professional photographer Freeman Patterson describes photography as a hobby that provides people not only with a creative outlet, but actually improves their ability to appreciate their surroundings. Shows him teaching students his beliefs and techniques.

results.title: Leisure lines
results.creator_credit: New Films, South Australian Film Corporation and Terry Jennings
results.brief_description: Leisure and recreation are becoming increasingly important to people in the community. Its important that there be some physical side to it and also enjoyment and relaxation. In addition, as this film points out, good facilities and community organisations are required to help people make the most of their leisuretime. Produced for the South Australian Department of Tourism, Recreation and Sport.

results.title: Leisure
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Maija Rove
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
In this second episode we are introduced to simple vocabulary associated with leisure activities and the phrases “Do you like?”, “What do you like?”, “How many times?” as well as vocabulary associated with weather and family members. The calligraphy section shows words which include “ball”, eg. “football”, “volleyball”, etc. The program concludes with two short dramatised situations “The TV addict” and “The Picnic” in which a Chinese couple are introduced to the joys of the Australian barbecue. In Mandarin and English.

results.title: Leila [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Farabi Cinema Foundation, Dariush Mehrjui and Faramarz Farazmand
results.brief_description: Considered as the founder of modern Iranian cinema, one of Iran’s greatest modern directors (alongside Kiarostami and Makmalbaf) and that country’s “longest-running cinematic master”, Dariush Mehrjui lacks the international profile of his contemporaries. “Leila” is one of just a handful of his films that have achieved recognition and distribution outside of Iran. Set firmly in the urban world of contemporary middle-class Tehran, the film centres on besotted newlywed couple Leila and Reza. Their happy life together begins to unravel after Leila finds herself unable to conceive. While the couple are unconcerned about this development, Reza’s mother is determined that her son have children, and insists that he must take a second wife to produce a heir and continue the family line. When Reza refuses to give in to her demands she turns to Leila, beating down her resistance to the idea with a mix of pleading, haranguing, and lies, until the couple limply gives in. An understated, yet devastating story of a happy union destroyed by the pressures of family and tradition. In Farsi with English subtitles.
